data.event: Situated 7 miles to the west of Cambridge, the population at the time of the 2001 census was 214.

event.title: the time of the Domesday Book in 1086

data.event: It remained in the possession of the crown at the time of the Domesday Book in 1086.

event.title: medieval times, and was the third most-populous parish in Longstow hundred in 1327

data.event: The village thrived in medieval times, and was the third most-populous parish in Longstow hundred in 1327.

event.title: 1306 the lord of the manor, Constantine Mortimer, was granted

data.event: In 1306 the lord of the manor, Constantine Mortimer, was granted the right to hold a weekly market on Tuesdays, as well as two annual fairs around the festivals of St Margaret and St Luke (19–21 July and 17–19 October).

event.title: a weekly market on Tuesdays, as well as two annual fairs around the festivals of St Margaret and St Luke (19–21 July

data.event: In 1306 the lord of the manor, Constantine Mortimer, was granted the right to hold a weekly market on Tuesdays, as well as two annual fairs around the festivals of St Margaret and St Luke (19–21 July and 17–19 October).

In 1306 the lord of the manor, Constantine Mortimer, was granted the right to hold a weekly market on Tuesdays, as well as two annual fairs around the festivals of St Margaret and St Luke (19–21 July and 17–19 October).

event.title: lapsed at some point over the next few centuries

data.event: The market and fairs lapsed at some point over the next few centuries and the population fell sharply to leave Kingston as one of the smallest parishes by population.
